bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Bert W. Caldwell, August 17, 1922

div1.p: Carter reviews, in detail, the "Report of the Yellow Fever Campaign in Second Yellow Fever Zone."

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carterto Bert W. Caldwell, August 17, 1922
div1.opener:
N. H. B.
Caldwell
/LC
New Glasgow P. O.,
Amherst County, Va.
“Geddes.” August 17, 1922.
Dr. Bert W. Caldwell,
Calle Constitucion No. 13,
Vera Cruz, Mexico.
Dear Doctor Caldwell:
div1.p:
I received your letter of Aug. 5th., enclosing your Report of the
Yellow Fever Campaign in the Second Yellow Fever Zone, last night, and
am answering as soon as I read the latter.

1) Your description of the sanitary condition of the 2nd. Zone in
the beginning of 1921 is very clear. I have no map here, but know about
where the Districts and towns you mention are and so can follow you.

I did not know that the efficacy of fish in Mexico was first demon-
stratedd at Tampico. You imply during the work under the Associated Oil
Managers. Just who was in direct charge? Who suggested them?

2) I think it was wise to divide up the too large Vera Cruz Di--
vision and make it into two. Any area as large as this was--with the
Tampico District--cannot be properly supervised by one man.

3) Your account of the fever in the Papaloapam Valley is extremely
interesting. It is the same condition which tended to continue yellow
fever in the sisal haciendas of Yucatan: the sugar fincas of Coro and which
might have made the sugar and rice country of Libertad and Lambayeque
a permanent endemic focus. Note that I draw a distinction between “en-
demic” and “permanently endemic.” The 1st. is determined by the bio-
logy of the Stegomyia: the 2nd. by that and the supply of susceptible
men.

4) On Page 5 you note an error in the campaign in the Papaloapam
Valley. Your criticism is just. Under the conditions as you describe
them, to limit your work to places, or districts, infected is to take
grave risk. It is, indeed, more important to work in places liable to
liable to
2.
become infected and from which it will spread--to limit the extension
of the epidemic rather than to suppress it. Just as one throws water
on the buildings around a burning house. I wish you could get the
“Loose-Leaves” of the Article on Yellow Fever for the last half year
(March 1922) of the Nelson Loose-Leaf Medicine, where this is briefly
discussed. Write and ask the Publishers.

5) Page 6. I note with pleasure that no work was done at Tehuante-
pec, because it was immunized by a severe and recent epidemic. Would the
same thing have rendered Stegomyia work unnecessary at Ojitlan--or were
non-immunes continually coming in?

6) Pages 7 & 8: I like your account of the measures used for Stego-
myia control and also your estimate of their comparative importance.

I think your estimate of 8 days from egg to imago is, in general,
too short. I know Dupre's Reports, but in Panama we found 10 to 11 days
about the minimum in nature.

How did you examine for larvae? Not easy to do it quickly and ef-
ficiently.

7) Hanson found the Life (Pygidium punctulatum Piurae (Eigenman)--
looks like a small cat-fish) the best for his use. Feeds at the bottom
in the day--on the top at night. Never grows big enough to be eaten,
nor jumps out of the water, and is very hardy. You may not have them on
the Gulf side.

8) Permanent covering of cisterns is of all measures the best--ex-
cept the doing away with them--for permenent freedom from Stegomyia, but
needs continual inspection.

9) Pages 9:10 & 11: I do not know the conditions in Mexico at
first hand and so can't judge, but your principle is right. It there
be any reasonable doubt that yellow fever is eliminated the Stegomyia
control should be continued until this doubt becomes certainty. The
work done would otherwise be lost--and, indeed, worse than lost--as one
could scarcely get a community to go through a second anti-stegomyia
campaign after what they would consider the failure of a first one.

For this reason, the campaign was continued in Peru until June of
this year--practically a year after the last reported case of yellow
fever and up to a fairly cool season of from 3 to 4 months. Stegomyia
control was carried out in all key-places--whether infected or not--
some over 300 miles from any known focus.

10) I lay little stress on reports of isolated cases of yellow
fever--preceeded by none for a long time and followed by none. They
are rarely yellow fever. Such was the Grillo case in New Orleans: 1899:
the case in New Iberia, La.: 1906:, in Colon, May 1907 etc. The Colon
case, I feel quite sure now, was a spirochetosis--probably Weil's Dis-
ease. I did not know at the time, but was quite sure it was not yellow
fever.
With every good wish, in which Laura, who is typing this, joins
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Address
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C., U. S. A.
